data.title: Keybindings with 'cmd' won't work on Linux
data.body:
On Linux, packages that specified 'cmd' in their keybinding sequences won't respond to any keyboard shortcuts, because there's no cmd key on Linux.

I see the platform-specific solution like `.platform-linux`, but I don't think package authors would like to add extra keybindings.

Can we solve this issue elegantly, like mapping cmd to ctrl on platforms other than darwin? I'm aware there's ctrl key on darwin, too, but it doesn't seem to be so useful (except in Terminal), like the corresponding super key on Linux.

data.body: GitHub for Windows makes a lot of the path issues easier, but we left out the part where they need to click 'Git Shell'

data.title: Build fails if user's npm doesn't recognize the version format ^X.Y.Z
data.body: The newest version of npm [1.4.10](https://www.npmjs.org/package/npm) has [read-package-json](https://github.com/npm/read-package-json/blob/master/package.json) as a nested dependency. Unfortunately read-package-json's package.json has a version string with the ^X.Y.Z pattern. This means that Atom's script/build will fail on version of npm that don't support that pattern.

data.title: Gutter selection issues
data.body:
(Ported from http://discuss.atom.io/t/gutter-selection-bug/8719, issue occurred on 0.93.0, as-yet-untested on 0.94.0, though the release notes for 0.94.0 don't say anything about selection issues being fixed.)

I have found a few issues with selections. Over the course of the beta a few have been solved but one remains, and it has an ugly cousin.

The simple point is that when making a selection, if the cursor (which still held down in  a drag) crosses over the gutter between the line numbers and the editor area itself Atom seems to take this as 'the cursor is at the end of the line'. If you move the mouse beyond this gutter into the actual line numbers, we're back to normal.

The ugly cousin is that if the line being selected is longer than the editor window (and there's no wrapping), thus selecting the end of the line would cause the editor to scroll, there's a nice back-and-forth game it likes to play.

I am currently unable to upload a gif, but see [my original post](http://discuss.atom.io/t/gutter-selection-bug/8719) for now if you want to see both of these in action.

Update: Gif!

![crazy-selection](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/412784/2913979/3e3eed40-d694-11e3-97d8-e28f78dec64c.gif)

data.title: Fix running .cmd stubs through BufferedProcess
data.body:
ChildProcess.spawn only will run .exe files on Windows, not .cmd, .bat, .anythingElse.

See joyent/node#2318 for more information.

data.title: Wordsmith the Atom readme
data.body: This is designed to reduce the word repetition in the into of the readme. The overall goal was to improve the cadence, but I also wanted to give some credit to the sources of inspiration. I also opted to leave out "modern" and "approachable" as these should be standards, rather than selling points.

data.title: Desktop file produced by script/grunt mkdev isn't working
data.body:
Following the installation guide for Linux in the README I ran into some problems using the `.desktop` file produced (See #1969 ). The atom icon shows up, but nothing happens when I hit it.

Running Debian Sid 3.14 with GNOME Shell 3.8.4.

A little summary:

```
htor@ultra:~/.local/src/atom$ script/grunt mkdeb
Running "mkdeb" task
Done, without errors.
htor@ultra:~/.local/src/atom$ cd /tmp/
htor@ultra:/tmp$ file atom-build
atom-build: Debian binary package (format 2.0)
htor@ultra:/tmp$ sudo dpkg -i atom-build
(Reading database ... 194042 files and directories currently installed.)
Preparing to unpack atom-build ...
Unpacking atom (0.95.0) over (0.95.0) ...
Setting up atom (0.95.0) ...
Processing triggers for desktop-file-utils (0.22-1) ...
Processing triggers for gnome-menus (3.8.0-2) ...
Processing triggers for mime-support (3.54) ...
htor@ultra:/tmp$ sudo dpkg -L atom 
/.
/usr
/usr/share
/usr/share/applications
/usr/share/applications/Atom.desktop
/usr/share/pixmaps
/usr/share/pixmaps/atom.png
/usr/bin
/usr/bin/atom
htor@ultra:/usr/share/applications$ cat Atom.desktop
[Desktop Entry]
Name=Atom
Comment=A hackable text editor for the 21st Century.
Exec=/usr/share/atom/atom %U
Icon=atom
Type=Application
StartupNotify=true
Categories=GNOME;GTK;Utility;TextEditor;
htor@ultra:/usr/share/applications$
```

Hmm, I wonder what the `/usr/share/atom/atom` is..

```
htor@ultra:/usr/share/applications$ file /usr/share/atom/atom
/usr/share/atom/atom: cannot open `/usr/share/atom/atom' (No such file or directory)
```

Apparently nothing. Let's change that to where `atom` was actually installed:

```
Exec=/usr/local/bin/atom
```

Now it works and I can launch atom normally.

data.title: Make Atom smarter about guessing if a file uses soft or hard tabs
data.body:
Previously, block commits would screw up tab prediction. For example:

```
/**ruby
  * I'm a docblock directly at the start of a file with a space to line up the docblock
  */
```

Atom would previously assume this file uses softTabs because of the block comment using leading spaces. Now Atom will ignore comments when figuring out if a file uses soft or hard tabs.

data.title: Windows multi-cursor functionality missing.
data.body: Ctrl-D does nothing, as does ctrl-leftclick. Is multi-cursor functionality missing from windows builds?

data.title: TokenizedBuffer::lineForScreenRow actually takes buffer rows.
data.body:
`TokenizedBuffer::lineForScreenRow` actually uses buffer rows.

It makes the method `Editor::lineForScreenRow` confusing. It should probably be broken up into `Editor::screenLineForScreenRow` and `Editor::tokenizedLineForBufferRow`.

data.title: Try using sips to create the atom icon
data.body:
We could run this in the build script. We might not even need to checkin the icns file.

`sips -s format icns atom.png --out atom.icns`

data.title: Performance degradation with react-editor
data.body: I opened a yaml file with 24651 lines in Atom. When the file is opened, I can scroll down (using the scroll bar) to the bottom of the file relatively smoothly. Colorization lags by a second or two, but it's definitely usable. Once I turn on the react editor, scrolling using the scroll bar becomes a hot mess. The editor freezes up when the scroll button is dragged, then unfreezes, then freezes, etc.
